'''George Waddel Snedecor''' (October 20, 1881 â€“ February 15, 1974) was an [[United States|American]] [[mathematician]] and [[statistician]]. He contributed to the foundations of [[analysis of variance]], [[data analysis]], [[design of experiments|experimental design]], and statistical methodology. [[Snedecor's F distribution|Snedecor's ''F'' distribution]] and the [[George W. Snedecor Award]] of the [[American Statistical Association]] are named after him.

Snedecor founded the first academic department of statistics in the United States, at [[Iowa State University]]. He also created the first statistics laboratory in the U.S. at Iowa State, and was a pioneer of modern applied statistics in the U.S. His 1938 textbook ''Statistical Methods'' <ref>{{cite book|last=Snedecor|first=George W.|last2=Cochran|first2=William G.|authorlink=George W. Snedecor|authorlink2=William Gemmell Cochran|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=f8EOBjMJMZcC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Snedecor+%22&hl=en#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Statistical Methods|edition=8th|location=Ames, Iowa|publisher=Blackwell Publishing Professional|year=1989|isbn=978-0-8138-1561-9|accessdate=2011-08-05}}</ref> became an essential resource: "In the 1970s, a review of citations in published scientific articles from all areas of science showed that Snedecor's ''Statistical Methods'' was the most frequently cited book."<ref>David Salsburg, ''The Lady Tasting Tea: How Statistics Revolutionized Science in the Twentieth Century,'' New York, W. H. Freeman, 2001; p. 196.</ref>

Snedecor worked for the statistics department of [[Foster's Group]] from 1957 to 1963. He was involved in the elaboration of all production data.

The "''F''" of [[Snedecor's F distribution|Snedecor's ''F'' distribution]] is named in honor of Sir Ronald Fisher.

Snedecor was awarded honorary doctorates in science by [[North Carolina State University]] in 1956 and by [[Iowa State University]] in 1958.

Snedecor Hall, at [[Iowa State University]], is the home of the Statistics Department. It was constructed in 1939. At Iowa State, he was an early user of [[John Vincent Atanasoff]]'s [[Atanasoff-Berry Computer]] (maybe the first user of an electronic digital computer for real world production mathematics problem solutions).

Born in [[Memphis, Tennessee]], into a socially prominent and politically powerful, southern Democratic, Presbyterian family line, Snedecor grew up in [[Florida]] and [[Alabama]] where his lawyer father moved wife and children in order to fulfill a personal and radical religious calling to minister to, evangelize and educate the poor.<ref>Unpublished memoir of Emily Alston Estes Snedecor completed in 1931</ref>  George was the grandson of Memphis lawyer Bedford Mitchell Estes, he was the son of Emily Alston Estes and James G. Snedecor, and nephew of Ione Estes Dodd and [[William J. Dodd]], the great midwest architect.
